front.div:
ABSTRACT
Artificially layered materials of alternating 2-3 nm thick copper and nickel layers have been produced by electrodepo-
sition on oriented single-crystal copper substrates. X-ray diffraction examination of thin layers chemically removed from
the substrate showed that a coherent, relatively homogeneous coating, with a strong epitaxial relationship, had been pro-
duced. In particular, artificially layered Cu-Ni alloys displaying a textured [110] orientation were obtained by electrodepo-
sition. Noncoherent nucleation leads to the presence of various amounts of randomly oriented alloy grains on all sub-
strates but, in particular, for the [100] orientation.

Microlayered metallic materials, sometimes referred to
as composition modulated alloys, have gained general rec-
ognition as the result of their unusual and sometimes out-
standing properties. These materials have been the subject
of numerous and intensive studies, the results of which,
along with the various predictive models, have been re-
viewed several times over the past years (1-5). The over-
whelming majority of these materials was prepared by
vacuum evaporation or by sputtering. These techniques
are well suited to the preparation of individual layers as
thin as 1 or 2 nm that can be stacked up by using ingenious
experimental techniques to produce relatively thick films.
Various techniques and, in particular, x-ray diffraction
were used to characterize the microlayered materials and
provided unambiguous evidence regarding the coherence,
the spacing, and the uniformity of the layered structure.
Microlayered metallic materials have been produced by
other investigators using electrodeposition. Brenner (6)
was the first to produce composition modulated Cu-Bi al-
